text: for today's video the idea is to take
the simplest most lifeless drawing I can
think of a single line and then seeing
how much life and animation I can put
into that line so I'll make three flip
books and in each one I'm gonna see what
I can do just with animating a simple
line first I'd like to thank Squarespace
for sponsoring this video from websites
and online stores to marketing tools and
analytics Squarespace is the all-in-one
platform to build a beautiful online
presence and run your business ok so I
wanted to put some life into this line
so my first thought was to kind of make
it try to pop itself up into the air so
it tries to lift itself up once this
goes back down the second time it goes
up a little further so you're kind of
building that that tension that I
thought I could have it start kind of
vibrating and build up that energy and
then pop itself up so this is that
tension thing again that I've talked
about before whenever you can do
something in your animation to build up
more and more potential energy it's a
lot more satisfying when you then
release that energy into an action now
once that line got up here I thought it
looked almost hair like sort of floaty
or lightweight so I gave it a little
hang time up in the air before it falls
back down the only unfortunate thing
you'll notice that the line now is a lot
longer than when it started so I guess
it's time to scrap it and do it all over
again just kidding that's why I number
my pages
okay so let's we'll go ahead and skip
ahead here and look at the finished
animation
[Music]
for my second flip book I decided to do
something a little different and that
was to keep the line stiff like a stick
and do something more based in
naturalistic physics like dropping a
stick from above and seeing how it
bounces I shot a slow motion video to
use as reference so I took a wooden
stick I dropped it and then I could go
through that video frame by frame and
really study how it was moving and
bouncing from frame to frame so based on
what was happening in that video I first
mapped out my path for the line to drop
down from above and it's funny because
despite the fact that I was studying
actual video reference you would think
it would be easier to do this but the
animation was actually a little more
difficult than I expected it was just it
was harder to get it looking right here
for example after it bounces up when it
begins falling back down the gravity is
all wrong it's falling to the right so
here I threw out the last several pages
and then I did that part again and
straightened out the fall and so from
here on out I was checking my animation
much more often I was test flipping it
nearly every page and that's something
about trying to do very realistic or
naturalistic animation when the physics
aren't quite right it can really look
off because we're so naturally very in
tune with how real life objects move and
behave so it can be a little trickier to
get it looking right and then it
happened again here after looking at the
bounce I realized it was bouncing way
too high so to fix that I pulled out
each page that was going too high then
traced each one of those pages and I
just offset the new pages so it would
end up being lower this flip book was
actually a really good exercise in in
learning how something moves if all I
did was to just watch the slow motion
video of a stick falling I wouldn't have
learned as much but I found that by
having to animate that same action I
really had to study each frame and see
what was happening frame by frame so
that I could replicate it so in the end
here's how it came out
[Music]
for the third flip book I went back to
doing something a little more playful
along the lines of the first one and I
had an idea to make the line kind of
shoot around the page bouncing off the
edges of the page to give it a sense of
fast speed I went with really big
increments here and I made the lines
really long so it feels like it's just
moving covering a lot of ground each
frame but at this point after it landed
after zipping around so fast I felt like
I wanted to smooth out the motion a bit
so I went back and I added in-between
frames so by lining up two pages to
trace over I could see where my
in-between drawing needed to be so after
adding all the in-between pages it
slowed the motion somewhat but then you
can flip it faster and it feels smoother
next I decided to have the line roll up
along the sides of the page this is this
is all just totally random and actually
that's what I really liked about doing
flip books like this it's like it's like
doodling it's kind of relaxing in that
way they're really quick
and you kind of just wander with your
ideas and kind of do whatever you think
of it slow pressure - you don't have to
have like a big epic story idea you can
just have fun and kind of play around
with movement as it rolls up along the
sides it's it's a really fast movement
here again and I also wanted to smooth
out this part but I wanted to keep the
speed I didn't want to add any
in-between frames so all I had to do was
draw motion blurs on the pages and then
I could keep the same speed but it feels
smoother and less strobing I love doing
this too because of how simple it is
it's like it's the perfect thing to try
if you don't feel like you can draw well
because you literally don't even have to
be able to draw a stick figure so just
experiment play around with movement and
see what you can do this one was really
fun it ended up being a pretty big stack
of paper in the end so let's go ahead
and jump to the end and see the finished
animation
[Music]
